title: Florida Decided to Let Teachers Carry Guns but Few Are
text:
As a new school year starts, Florida’s plan to allow armed teachers as a defense against shootings has fallen flat.

Only seven of Florida’s 67 county school districts—Bay, Gilchrist, Lafayette, Levy, Okeechobee, Putnam and Suwannee—say they have approved or would consider arming teachers, according to a survey of school officials by The Wall Street Journal. Three others—Baker, Jackson and Okaloosa—wouldn’t say whether they have authorized the move.

None of the state’s largest 25 districts, including Miami-Dade, Broward and Orange, have approved the program. With the exception of Bay County, home to Panama City, they all are small, mostly rural counties.

Guns in Schools In 2019, so far 18 states have considered legislation related to arming school employees. Much of it concerns allowing firearms for designated security personnel, but some bills address arming teachers and staff more broadly. “Teachers have a lot on their plates,” said Tamara Shamburger, chairwoman of the Hillsborough County school board, in Tampa, which voted unanimously against arming instructors. “Their focus has to be on educating their kids and not fighting off bad guys.”

A month after the 2018 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., that killed 17 people, the state passed a law that included a new guardian program. It allowed for the arming of certain school personnel, but not teachers, who volunteered and underwent training and background checks.

This year, lawmakers passed a school-security bill that expanded the guardian program to allow teachers to participate if a county school board approves, despite opposition from many educators, parents and students. A state commission created in the wake of the Parkland shooting recommended it, along with other safety measures.

At least eight other states, including Kansas and Texas, allow some teachers or other school employees to have guns, according to the Education Commission of the States, which tracks legislation.

There are now 3,156 law-enforcement officers and 1,062 guardians assigned to Florida’s public schools, according to a presentation last month by the state’s Department of Education. The agency didn’t break out how many of the guardians are teachers, but based on school district responses to the Journal, it likely is a tiny fraction.

In Bay County, school board members approved the arming of teachers as an added layer of security, said Bill Husfelt, the schools superintendent. He was involved in a 2010 incident that he said left the school district scarred. A disgruntled man entered the school board’s meeting room and shot at Mr. Husfelt and other members, missing them all before getting shot by a security guard and committing suicide.

“We’ve got to meet these fears and challenges head on,” Mr. Husfelt said. “We’ve got to give the teachers another way when possible.”

Florida Senate President Bill Galvano said he and other supporters of the measure sought to fulfill the recommendations of the state commission. They wanted to give school districts a variety of options, from traditional school resource officers to newly trained guardians.

“My concern is that they have adequate security,” Mr. Galvano said. “We wanted to give them an additional tool.”

Fedrick Ingram, president of the Florida Education Association, the state teachers union, said the policy burdens instructors with an enormous responsibility for which they have little expertise. It also could endanger students if any were to get hold of a firearm inadvertently left unguarded, he said.

Sheriff Bob Gualtieri spoke at a news conference on school safety initiatives in Sunrise, Fla., on Aug. 14. Photo: Amy Beth Bennett/TNS/Zuma Press

An analysis updated last month by the Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence, a gun-control policy organization, found that there have been 74 publicly reported incidents of mishandled guns at U.S. schools in the past five years. The incidents included a teacher unintentionally firing a gun in class during a safety demonstration and a loaded gun falling from a teacher’s waistband on a school playground.

Programs to arm teachers are “a potential liability waiting to happen,” said Ken Trump, president of National School Safety and Security Services, a consulting firm that provides violence-prevention training. “The vast majority of superintendents and principals and school boards have absolutely no desire to arm their staff.”

Write to Arian Campo-Flores at arian.campo-flores@wsj.com
